title: Language-Based Instructional Design Utilizing Segmented Video for Basketball Tactical Learning

context.prior_knowledge: Comprehension of basic basketball terminology (e.g., 'dribble', 'shoot', 'rebound') and intermediate-level tactical explanation and verbal communication skills
context.additional_context: Targets novices in managerial/leadership roles, emphasizing enhanced tactical understanding through combined linguistic explanations (tactical terminology, directives) and visual aids (segmented videos), with a focus on strengthening effective communication skills in sports contexts.

learning_goals: Learners explain core elements of basketball tactics through segmented videos (macro/micro segments) by combining linguistic descriptions (terminology, instructions) with visual aids at 80% accuracy.

Learners achieve a game performance assessment score of 75 or higher (out of 100) in morning learning sessions and accurately use tactical vocabulary (e.g., 'screen', 'cut', 'pass') during evaluations.

During the mid-course (weeks 2–4), learners apply three language expressions related to basketball tactics (e.g., 'positioning', 'teamwork', 'strategy') weekly via formative assessments and incorporate over 80% of evaluator feedback into the next week's practice.
difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
